title: 112_hr6635
content: The "TRICARE Protection Act" allows for the future availability of TRICARE Prime throughout the United States. The Secretary of Defense must submit a report to Congress within 90 days of the Act's enactment detailing the future availability of TRICARE Prime for eligible beneficiaries in all TRICARE regions across the United States. The report should include a description of the availability differences by region under newly awarded TRICARE managed care contracts. The report to Congress must include details on TRICARE Prime availability in different regions under new managed care contracts, ensuring affected beneficiaries retain access to care, estimating increased costs, and projecting Department savings. The Department plans to assess the impact on access to health care for affected beneficiaries and develop a plan that includes establishing a navigator service and allowing enrollment in TRICARE Prime Remote if necessary. The Secretary will identify affected beneficiaries without access to a primary care provider meeting TRICARE standards and implement a plan within 60 days of submitting a report. The Secretary will implement a plan to ensure affected beneficiaries have access to a primary care provider meeting TRICARE standards within one to two years. Monitoring of access will be conducted as per Section 711 of the National Defense. The National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2008 is amended to ensure affected beneficiaries have access to a primary care provider meeting TRICARE standards. Monitoring of access will be conducted in regions where TRICARE Prime is no longer available. The National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2008 is amended to ensure affected beneficiaries have access to a primary care provider meeting TRICARE standards, specifically for eligible beneficiaries under newly awarded TRICARE managed care contracts in fiscal years 2013 through 2015. This includes assessing access for affected eligible beneficiaries to a primary care provider that meets TRICARE access standards. The National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2008 is amended to ensure affected beneficiaries enrolled in TRICARE Prime have access to a primary care provider meeting TRICARE standards. This applies to eligible beneficiaries under newly awarded TRICARE managed care contracts in fiscal years 2013 through 2015, residing in regions where TRICARE Prime enrollment will no longer be available. The term "TRICARE access standards" refers to standards developed to prevent excessive wait times or travel times for healthcare access. The term "TRICARE Prime" refers to the managed care option of the TRICARE program, while "TRICARE access standards" are developed to ensure beneficiaries have timely access to healthcare.
